Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: The Impact Of Agriculture On Social Complexity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Under the supervision of Dr. Robert Jeske, Mr. Richard Edwards will investigate the relationship between subsistence strategies and the development of cultural complexity among early agricultural populations. Traditional literature suggests a close relationship between the development of agriculture with stratified social systems and cultural institutions. Archaeology is well suited to investigate this question by examining prehistoric societies that seem to have taken more egalitarian approaches. The deep historical view of archaeology allows researchers to understand the long-term trajectory of changes in subsistence strategies. Within this broad framework, this project provides concrete benefits for archaeologists, students, and the public. This project will help to understand the effects of changing subsistence strategies during a time of environmental change - the shift from the Medieval Warm Period to the Little Ice Age. The additional knowledge about the effects of climate change on subsistence and societies will prove beneficial to science in general. This analysis will not require the destruction of human remains, reducing tension between archaeologists and Native Americans. A publicly available online database will include raw data, facilitating future research by other scholars. Finally, this project provides educational opportunities for other graduate and undergraduate students at multiple universities during the data-collection and reporting phases

The researchers will investigate the role of maize (corn) agriculture and the development of social/political complexity in the Eastern US and Canada from AD1000-1600. As people increased the use of maize in their diet at this time, a variety of transformations in other cultural institutions occurred. Middle Mississippian groups in the southern parts of the region saw a significant rise in social and political stratification. However, Oneota groups near the Great Lakes maintained remarkably egalitarian social structures. Crucially, archaeologists do not know how maize utilization varied between Middle Mississippian and Oneota populations. Traditional subsistence analyses can identify important crops, but cannot accurately measure the relative importance of one food source to another. Isotopic analysis of bones can accurately determine the proportion of maize to other foods eaten by an individual. Unfortunately, these analyses are destructive, and few have been undertaken on human remains in the region. Current data suggest that Oneota and Middle Mississippian groups may have consumed roughly equal amounts of maize but with significant regional variation. This study uses isotopes to understand the dietary makeup of Oneota groups in Wisconsin. To avoid destroying human bone, this project uses the Canine Surrogacy Approach. CSA is premised on the idea that dogs can act a proxy for humans. Dogs often eat human food and feces, and therefore have similar isotopic signatures to their owners. This project will test all dogs recovered from Oneota sites in Wisconsin and Illinois to determine the relative importance of maize agriculture to hunting and fishing. Combined with other datasets, this analysis will contextualize the role of subsistence practices with the social and political systems used by Oneota groups relative to their neighbors during a time of shifting climate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on using the Canine Surrogacy Approach (CSA) to determine the prehistoric importance of agriculture in the Great Lakes region, to explore the relationship between agriculture and the development of social inequality. Early in the history of the discipline, anthropologists thought that agriculture was a stage of human cultural evolution. Many argued that once groups developed agriculture and surplus food, they had the incentive and means to develop hierarchical political offices and social institutions. Along with these institutions came different classes or castes. Over the decades, anthropologists refined their understanding of culture, realizing each society exists on its own trajectory. Each society is shaped by its own unique history and environment. Still, the association of agriculture with the development of hierarchical forms of leadership, monumental architecture, and other aspects of complex social organization was largely persevered.

     One reason for such preservation is exemplified in 11th-17th century populations in the Mississippi River Valley and American Southeast, called Middle Mississippians by archaeologists. These southern groups developed hierarchical social structures including a ruling elite class, inherited chiefdoms, and monumental architecture.

     But in many cases, there has been enough conflicting data to question the association between agriculture and social complexity. For example, archaeologists have long known that during the 11th-17th centuries in the Upper Midwest, a number of societies collectively referred to as Oneota used domesticated crops as part of their diet. In particular, they grew maize (corn), but did not develop social stratification.  Many have downplayed this apparent contradiction by assuming Oneota groups grew less maize than their southern neighbors. Unfortunately, insufficient data were available to test this assumption.

      As research on Oneota groups continued, the idea they consumed little maize became increasingly doubtful. Stable isotope analysis of human bones is one way to measure the amount of certain foods in the diet. Levels of δ13C (delta carbon 13) measures the importance of tropical plants (e.g., maize) and δ15N (delta Nitrogen 15) measures animal protein intake. In 2005, using the levels of δ13C in archaeologically recovered human bones, archaeologists assessed maize consumption by groups in northern Illinois. The tests indicate egalitarian groups in northern Illinois ate maize at levels on par with many of their Middle Mississippian neighbors. However, only Oneota groups closest to Middle Mississippians were included, which is only a small geographic subset of Oneota. More data were needed to advance our understanding of how agriculture and social inequality were related.

     Restricted by practical, ethical, and legal issues, often, this information is not easily obtained. On a basic level, human remains are absent from many sites, and the research is expensive. Most importantly, stable isotope analysis requires the destruction of small amounts of bone. Many Native American tribes object to the destruction of skeletal remains for research, citing ethical and religious reasons. Their concerns have been integrated in some national and state laws. In Wisconsin, among other states, destructive testing of Native American human remains is rarely allowed. As a core Oneota territory, Wisconsin’s prohibition limits isotopic research.

     Luckily, researchers around the globe developed CSA, which uses dog remains to approximate human values. As close companions to humans, dogs are often fed or scavenge human foods, particularly prior to commercial dog food. Dogs also scavenge human feces, thereby literally eating the same food. Thus, their diets contain foods in similar proportions to their humans making their bone chemistry very similar. In cases where one cannot test human remains, dog remains should produce comparable results.

     To estimate Oneota maize consumption, this project analyzed dog remains from sites across Wisconsin and northern Illinois. The results were similar to the 2005 Illinois study. On average, people at Oneota sites ate a similar amount of maize as Middle Mississippians. But the picture is more complicated than that. At all Oneota sites, canine data indicate most people received approximately 40-60% of their protein from maize with little variation.

     Analyses of human remains from Middle Mississippian sites in southwestern Illinois show considerable variation. Elites ate little maize and considerable amounts of meat; urban commoners ate almost nothing but maize; rural commons with access to woodlands added some wild plants to their maize heavy diet. Whereas Oneota populations, regardless of where they lived or social status, consumed similar yet substantial amounts of maize, bolstered with both wild plants and animals.

     This new understanding of Oneota diets tells us that agriculture does not necessarily lead to social inequality. Agricultural societies can be socially and politically egalitarian. The big distinction is not that agricultural crops are grown and eaten, but it is in how food is distributed. In situations where other conditions are right for social inequality to form (e.g., large and dense populations), agriculture may be a contributing cause, but it does not have to lead in that direction.
